ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Is equivalent to specifying the OBSERVED, RP, CP, CELLCHI2, EXPECTED, and DEVIATION options.
Displays adjusted inertias when performing multiple correspondence analysis.

Enables you to create binary tables easily. When you specify the BINARY option, specify only column 
variables in the TABLES statement. Each input data set observation forms a single row in the constructed table.
Displays the contribution to the total chi-square test statistic for each cell.

Provides other standardizations of the column coordinates. The COLUMN= option is rarely needed. 
Typically, you should use the PROFILE= option instead.

Displays the column profile matrix. Column profiles contain the observed conditional probabilities
of row membership given column membership.
Specifies the method of crossing (factorially combining) the levels of the TABLES variables.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes each combination of levels for all column variables to become a column label,  whereas each level of every row variable becomes a row label.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes each combination of levels for all row variables to become a row label, whereas each level of every column variable becomes a column label.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Causes each combination of levels for all row variables to become a row label and each combination of levels for all column variables to become a column label.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Causes each level of every row variable to become a row label and each level of every column variable to become a column label.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: DATA=SAS-data-set] 
      
Specifies the SAS data set to be used by PROC CORRESP.

Displays the matrix of deviations between the observed frequency matrix and the product 
of its row marginals and column marginals divided by its grand frequency.

[Syntax: DIMENS=n] 
      
Specifies the number of dimensions or axes to use. The default is DIMENS=2.

Displays the product of the row marginals and the column marginals divided by the grand frequency 
of the observed frequency table.

Indicates that the PROC CORRESP input data set has the same form as an output data 
set from the FREQ procedure, even if it was not directly produced by PROC FREQ. 
The FREQOUT option enables PROC CORRESP to take shortcuts in constructing the 
contingency table.
Displays adjusted inertias when you are performing multiple correspondence analysis.
Requests a multiple correspondence analysis.

[Syntax: MININERTIA=n] 
      
Specifies the minimum inertia (0 ≤ n ≤ 1) used to create the "best" tables—the 
indicator of which points best explain the inertia of each dimension.

Specifies that observations with missing values for the TABLES statement variables 
are included in the analysis. Missing values are treated as a distinct level of 
each categorical variable.

Suppresses the display of the column coordinates and statistics and omits them from 
the output coordinate data set.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Suppresses all column information from the output data set.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Suppresses all column information from the SAS listing.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Suppresses all column information from both the SAS listing and the output data set.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Suppresses the display of all output.

Suppresses the display of the row coordinates and statistics and omits them from the 
output coordinate data set.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Suppresses all row information from the output data set.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Suppresses all row information from the SAS listing.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Suppresses all row information from both the SAS listing and the output data set.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: NVARS=n] 
      
Specifies the number of classification variables that were used to create the Burt table.
Displays the contingency table of observed frequencies and its row, column, and grand totals.

[Syntax: OUTC=SAS-data-set] 
      
Creates an output coordinate SAS data set to contain the row, column, 
supplementary observation, and supplementary variable coordinates.

[Syntax: OUTF=SAS-data-set] 
      
Creates an output frequency SAS data set to contain the contingency table, row, 
and column profiles, the expected values, and the observed minus expected values 
and contributions to the chi-square statistic.

Specifies options that control the details of the plots.
      
Syntax: 
(1) PLOTS<(global-plot-options)> <= plot-request <(options)>> 
(2) PLOTS<(global-plot-options)> <= (plot-request <(options)> <... plot-request <(options)>>)>

The global plot option is as follows: 

  FLIP 
  FLI 
  flips or interchanges the X-axis and Y-axis dimensions. 

The plot requests include the following: 

  ALL 
  produces all appropriate plots. 

  NONE 
  NON 
  suppresses all plots.
Affects the OBSERVED, RP, CP, CELLCHI2, EXPECTED, and DEVIATION options. The default is PRINT=FREQ.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Displays output in the appropriate raw or natural units.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Scales results to percentages for the display of the output.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[plot request] 
      
Specifies the method of crossing (factorially combining) the levels of the 
TABLES variables.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies a correspondence analysis of the column profile matrix. The column coordinates are weighted centroids of the row coordinates.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies a correspondence analysis of the row profile matrix. The row coordinates are  weighted centroids of the column coordinates.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies a standard correspondence analysis, which jointly displays the principal row and column coordinates.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Is rarely needed. Row and column coordinates are the generalized singular vectors,  without the customary standardizations.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[plot request] 
      
Provides other standardizations of the row coordinates.

Displays the row profile matrix. Row profiles contain the observed conditional probabilities of column
membership given row membership.
Suppresses the display of all point and coordinate statistics except the coordinates.

[Syntax: SINGULAR=n] 
      
Specifies the largest value that is considered to be within rounding error of zero.

Adds the variable _VAR_, which contains the name or label of the variable corresponding 
to the current level, to the OUTC= and OUTF= data sets.
Displays unadjusted inertias when performing multiple correspondence analysis.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: BY <DESCENDING> variable-1 <...<DESCENDING> variable-n> <NOTSORTED>; 
      
Obtains separate analyses on observations in groups defined by the BY variables.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that 
immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.
Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ID variable ;
      
You specify the ID statement only in conjunction with the VAR statement. You cannot 
specify the ID statement when you use the TABLES statement or the MCA option. When 
you specify an ID variable, PROC CORRESP labels the rows of the tables with the ID 
values and places the ID variable in the output data set.

Syntax: VAR variables ;
      
You should specify the VAR statement when your data are in tabular form. The VAR 
variables must be numeric. The VAR statement instructs PROC CORRESP to read an 
existing contingency table, binary indicator matrix, fuzzy-coded indicator matrix, 
or Burt table, rather than raw data.

Syntax: WEIGHT variable;
      
The WEIGHT statement specifies weights for each observation and indicates supplementary 
observations for simple correspondence analyses with VAR statement input. You can include 
only one WEIGHT statement, and the weight variable must be numeric.

Syntax: SUPPLEMENTARY variables ;
      
The SUPPLEMENTARY statement specifies variables that are to be represented as points 
in the joint row and column space but that are not used in determining the locations 
of the other, active row and column points of the contingency table.
